Enter TODAY for a chance to WIN R5000 and fame throughout Africa

homechoice blankets are a much-loved favourite in homes across South Africa. Now, we are giving YOU the chance to design a brand-new blanket. You could WIN R5 000 in cash AND have your blanket added to the homechoice range and sold nationwide.

A panel of experts will select the top three designs, and the public will get to vote for the WINNER!

Cash prizes and nationwide fame
The WINNING design will receive R5 000 in cash, the opportunity to name the blanket and nationwide fame as the designer of a homechoice blanket.
The first runner up gets R3 000 in cash.
The second runner up walks away with R1 000 cash.
Are you interested? Here is what you need to know!

You need to create an original design for a woven blanket that is 200 x 230cm. You can only use up to 8 colours as the weaving process limits the number of colours used to create a blanket.

Here are some examples of woven blanket designs:

How to enter
  • Step 1: Send an email to competitions@homechoice.co.za
  • Step 2: Include “Design A Blanket” in the subject line of your email
  • Step 3: Be sure to include your name, surname, phone number and email address
  • Step 4: MOST IMPORTANT: Attach your design as a PDF and make sure it is no bigger than 5mb in file size.

You’ll need to hurry because entries close on 26 March 2022. Time is running out! Send your design to us today!

By entering, you agree to receive electronic and other marketing communications through text, emails and other electronic channels from homechoice and FinChoice Africa about their retail, credit, insurance and other financial services products. Your personal information will be processed in accordance with our privacy policy.

Should your entry be selected as a finalist, your profile and photo will be shared in our marketing material and on our social media accounts. homechoice will own the rights to the winning design, and the winner(s) will not earn any royalties from the sales. For more information, see our Ts&Cs.
